Graphical abstract Layered-double hydroxides (LDHs) based on copper, manganese, and aluminum were successfully prepared from sodium-free reactants, with x (Al3+/[Al3++Cu2++Mn2+]) values between 0.24 and 0.35, and y (Cu2+/Mn2+) values between 2.2 and 10.3. Catalysts obtained by calcination of the LDHs were characterized by EXAFS, XANES, XPS, ICP, XRD, TPR, N2O decomposition and BET, and were evaluated in the liquid-phase methanol synthesis reaction from synthesis gas. Characterization revealed that, in a commercial CuZnAl catalyst, the environment of copper is very similar to that prevailing in CuO. In the CuMnAl catalyst that presented the largest methanol synthesis activity, copper is more electron-deficient than in CuO and there is structural disorder beyond the first coordination sphere. TPR characterization suggests that manganese is in the 4+ oxidation state in the oxide precursor of this catalyst. The catalyst with the highest manganese content, y = 2.2, and prepared at higher pH, presented the highest methanol productivity and selectivity of all materials tested, including a commercial conventional CuZnAl catalyst, under our testing conditions. This was credited to the larger surface area of its oxide precursor, which resulted in smaller Cu crystallites and larger copper surface area than in the case of the remaining ones. Keywords Methanol synthesis Layered double hydroxides Hydrotalcite-Type materials Sodium-Free CuMnAl CuZnAl 1 Introduction Methanol is a compound of great industrial importance because of its use as raw material in the synthesis of many important chemical products. It can also be used as an energy carrier for hydrogen storage and as a fuel [1,2]. Methanol synthesis is an already well-established process, with an annual production of approximately 90 million tons. It consists of the hydrogenation of synthesis gas (CO x /H2 mixture), in a heterogeneous catalytic process [3–6]. The catalyst has been the center of constant research in the last 40 years [7] and is the main focus for the optimization of methanol synthesis [2], but mostly around the same ternary system, Cu/ZnO/Al2O3 [2,7–10]. Layered double hydroxides (LDHs) are minerals from the family of anionic clays. The general formula representing the LDHs is [M2+ 1- x M3+ x (OH−)2] x +[An- x /n].mH2O, where M2+ and M3+ are divalent and trivalent cations, respectively, An− is a compensation anion, m is the interlayer water and x is the molar fraction of the trivalent cation with respect to total cations. The preparation of the materials is simple and their composition allows a wide range of element combinations, as well as of their relative proportions. Catalysts resulting from LDH decomposition are generally mixed oxides with good active phase dispersion, thermally stable, and with high specific surface area [11]. In the present work, bulk catalysts were prepared from trimetallic LDHs, containing Mn, Cu and Al, keeping constant the x value (Al3+ molar fraction) at 0.19 (nominal value) and varying the Cu2+/Mn2+ molar ratio (y value). For the material with y = 0.5 (nominal value), two different precipitation pH values were used. The catalysts were evaluated in the liquid-phase methanol synthesis reaction from synthesis gas (syngas), using a conventional commercial CuZnAl catalyst as a reference. The liquid-phase methanol synthesis process was developed in 1975. Claimed distinguishing features include usage of CO-rich syngas, superior once-through conversion from syngas, higher heat transfer efficiency, and better heat management [12]. Previous work in the literature already show some benefits of adding manganese to methanol synthesis catalysts, but mainly as additives to the conventional CuZnAl system [13–17]. Turning our attention to LDH based catalysts, CuMnAl ternary structures are reported in the literature [18–23], however they were not evaluated in the methanol synthesis reaction. This work is part of broader project, where the methanol synthesis catalyst will be used in conjunction with a methanol dehydration one, in the direct synthesis of dimethyl ether from syngas in a slurry reactor. However, as alcohol dehydration reactions require acid sites and sodium is a poison for these sites, one of the objectives of this work was also to obtain methanol synthesis catalysts from sodium-free raw materials. There are reports in the literature on LDHs made from Na-free precipitating agents using NH4OH [24,25] or gaseous NH3 + CO2 [26], Na-free methanol synthesis catalysts also exist [27–30], however CuMnAl ternary LDHs have never been prepared from Na-free reactants using our method and they also were not evaluated in the methanol synthesis reaction, to the best of our knowledge. 2 Experimental 2.1 Preparation of the catalysts LDH precursors were prepared using the controlled pH precipitation method. Two solutions were added to a glass reactor with 200 ml of water. One solution containing metal nitrates in the appropriate proportions for the desired compositions (0.4 M in total divalent metal nitrates and 0.1 M in aluminum nitrate) and another 0.05 M in ammonium carbonate (the commercial name for a bicarbonate plus ammonium carbamate mixture) and 0.7 M in ammonium hydroxide. The pH (6.5 or 8.0) and temperature (338 K) were kept constant during precipitation. The suspension was aged for 18 h and, subsequently, the precipitate was filtered, washed abundantly with water and dried at 373 K for 4 h. Three ternary LDHs were prepared containing Al (trivalent metal) and Mn and Cu (divalent metals), all of them with nominal x value (Al molar fraction with respect to total metal elements) equal to 0.19, and nominal y (Cu/Mn molar ratio) values of 0.5 or 2.0. The precipitation pH for the sample with y = 2.0 was 6.5. For the LDHs prepared with y = 0.5, two precipitation pHs were used (pH = 6.5 or 8.0). The naming scheme adopted was CuMnYpHZ, where Y is the nominal value of the Cu/Mn molar ratio and Z is the precipitation pH. Thus, for example, CuMn2pH6.5 is the LDH with nominal molar ratio Cu/Mn equals 2.0 and precipitation pH equals 6.5. As a control, two binary LDHs were prepared as reference materials labeled as CupH6.5 and MnpH8. These materials were prepared as described above, using either only copper and aluminum (CupH6.5) or only manganese and aluminum (MnpH8) in their composition. To obtain the mixed oxides, the precursors were calcined at 673 K for 3 h with a heating rate of 10 K min−1. The naming scheme of the calcined materials is the same as used for the LDH precursors, with the addition of letter C. In reduced catalysts, whose obtention will be explained in Section 2.3, letter C is replaced by R. The commercial methanol synthesis catalyst (CuO-ZnO-Al2O3, called here CMSC) was obtained from PROSINT Química S.A. (Brazil). The Cu, Zn and Al molar fractions in the CMSC used as activity reference in this work are 0.56, 0.28 and 0.16, respectively, relative to total metal elements [31]. 2.2 Characterization X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns for the LDH precursors and for the mixed oxides were obtained in a Rigaku powder X-ray diffractometer, model Ultima IV, with a Cu Kα radiation (λ = 1.54056 Å), operated at 40 kV and 20 mA. The diffractograms were measured in the interval (2θ) between 5 and 80°, at 2° min−1. In situ XRD measurements were performed at the XPD-D10B beamline of the Brazilian Synchrotron Light Laboratory (LNLS). The wavelength used was 1.54922 Å A set of data was collected every 2 min, from room temperature to 538 K, with a 2θ interval of 25 to 55°. A heating rate of 10 K min−1 and 40 mL min−1 H2/He (5% v/v) flow-rate were used. Once the temperature of 538 K was reached, it was held constant for 40 min. X-Ray line broadening was used to estimate particle diameter of copper crystallites using Scherrer’s equation for in situ reduced samples: (1) D s = K λ β cos θ where: Ds is the particle diameter, λ is the wavelength of the X-Ray radiation (1.54922 Å), K is the Scherrer constant (1 for this work), θ is the angle of the diffraction peak. β is the peak width corrected for the instrument broadening, which, in this work, was the (003) reflection of an alumina standard, using the peak at 2θ 43.5°, and determined as; (2) β = ( B 2 − b 2 ) where B and b are the FWHM (full width at half maximum) from the sample of interest and the alumina standard, respectively. Both copper peaks at 2θ 43.31 and 50.44° were used for the calculation, with equivalent results. Elemental chemical analysis of the mixed oxides was carried-out by the Analytical Center of the University of São Paulo in an inductively coupled plasma optical spectrometer (ICP-OES, Radial) Spectrobrand, model Arcos. X-ray photoelectron spectra (XPS) of the mixed oxides were obtained in a Thermo Scientific ESCALAB 250 XI spectrometer, equipped with a X-ray tube with a double Al/Mg anode and concentric hemispherical analyzer. Surface concentrations of the elements in the samples were determined from survey XPS spectra. NIST database binding energies were used to establish the chemical environments. The linewidth of the photopeaks were determined measuring CuO, Cu2O, MnO, MnO2, Mn2O3, Mn3O4, Al2O3 reference samples. The energies in all spectra were corrected to 285 eV for C1 s. Binding energies and linewidth parameters are significant to 0.2 eV. Specific surface areas of the mixed oxides were determined by the BET method from N2 physisorption at 77 K in an automated volumetric Micromeritics equipment, ASAP 2010C model. The samples were pre-treated at 573 K until a degassing rate lower than 2 μm h−1 was obtained. In-situ X-Ray Absorption Spectroscopy (XANES and EXAFS) measurements were performed on the Cu K-edge at the XAFS2 beamline of the National Synchrotron Light Laboratory (LNLS) in Brazil. The spectra of the samples in the oxide state were collected under He atmosphere at 423 K. Thereafter, they were reduced in situ under H2/He (5%v/v) atmosphere at 538 K to study the Cu phases present in the catalyst in their active form. The experimental details are described in Section 1.1 of the Supplementary Information. Temperature-Programmed Reduction (H2-TPR) and N2O decomposition were performed in order to determine the copper dispersion. The experimental details are shown in Section 1.2 of the Supplementary Information. 2.3 Catalytic tests Catalytic activity measurements were carried-out in a 50 ml Autoclave Engineers continuously stirred tank reactor (CSTR). A catalyst mass in the range 0.20-0.37 g with granulometry in the 74–88 μm range was added to the reactor, suspended in 25 mL of n-hexadecane and reduced in situ under 50 bar hydrogen pressure, 538 K and stirring at 500 rpm for 18 h. At the end of the reduction, H2 was replaced by syngas (H2/CO = 2 mol basis) to start the reaction. Hydrogen (120 ml min−1) and syngas (170 ml min−1) flow-rates used in the reduction and in the reaction, respectively, were controlled by Brooks mass flow controllers. All gases passed through appropriate traps, in order to eliminate any contaminants, specially pentacarbonyl iron [32]. The composition of the reactor effluent was continuously monitored for 8 h by gas chromatography, using a Shimadzu GC-2010 instrument, equipped with a CP-Porabond Q (50 m x 0.32 mm x 0.45 μm) capillary column and a thermal conductivity detector (TCD). Each substance was identified and the areas were corrected for the TCD response factors, both obtained in the laboratory and extracted from the literature [31,33]. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Characterization of the precursor form of the catalysts 3.1.1 X-ray diffraction Fig. S1 presents the X-ray diffraction patterns of the LDH precursors. All samples, with exception of MnpH8, show intense and narrow lines at low 2θ values, while less intense and less symmetrical ones appear at high 2θ values, as typically seen in LDH diffraction patterns [11]. The diffractograms correspond to that of a CuAl LDH (PDF 46-0099). Comparison with a CuMnAl LDH standard was not possible because no XRD pattern was found for this system, either in PDF (Powder Diffraction File) or ICSD (Inorganic Crystal Structure Database) databases or in the open literature. In the case of CuAl LDH (CupH6.5), peaks extraneous to an LDH phase are observed at 2θ ca. 15°, 19°, 31°, and 35°. These peaks correspond to those of malachite, a copper hydroxycarbonate (ICSD 260,811). The peaks at 2θ ca. 31°, and 35° peaks are also seen with much diminished intensity in CuMn2pH6.5 and CuMn0.5pH6.5 but are absent in the XRD pattern for CuMn0.5pH8. Some reviews claim that it is not possible to obtain Cu-containing pure LDHs without the presence of other divalent cations [11,34] due to Jahn-Teller distortion. Nevertheless, the synthesis of practically pure CuAl-CO3 LDHs has been reported, but under especial conditions, such as excess carbonate, [18] and very low concentration of the metals (approximately 0.01 M) [35,36]. In the synthesis reported here no such conditions were used and, for this reason, besides the LDH phase, malachite, the recurrent impurity in copper LDH systems, was also produced. On the other hand, the absence of malachite in the trimetallic system CuMn0.5pH8 is a good indication that manganese was incorporated together with copper in the LDH structure. The c parameter, related to the size of the anion (CO3 2−), was calculated from the (003) reflection, while the a parameter, related to the ionic radii of the divalent cations (Cu2+ e Mn2+) and the value of x, was calculated from the (110) reflection, as explained in the Supplementary Information. These parameters are shown in Table S1. The values of a and c parameters determined are typical of LDHs and are consistent with the reported values for the anion [11,18] and cations [18] used in the syntheses. The a parameter obtained for material CuMn0.5pH8 is smaller than the ones of the other materials. The inset in Fig. S1 shows the 2θ region around the (110) reflection. Due to the low intensity of the XRD profiles in this region, a scan with 10x the accumulation time used for the overall diffractograms was performed in order to improve the signal-to-noise ratio. The peaks attributed to the (110) reflection in each case are highlighted with an arrow. The peak in LDH CuMn0.5pH8 is clearly shifted with respect to the other materials. This was also the same material where malachite peaks could not be observed, confirming that manganese was incorporated into the LDH structure at least in this case. The diffractograms of the mixed oxides (Fig. 1 ) show loss of the layered structure and of crystallinity when compared to the materials prior to calcination. The presence of the CuO phase in CupH6.5C, CuMn2pH6.5C and CMSC is verified, since the XRD patterns coincide with the one published for the tenorite form of CuO (ICSD 16,025). In the other two samples, the peaks are poorly defined, indicating that more amorphous materials were produced, and an amorphous halo appears around the region of the main CuO reflection. The CupH6.5C diffractogram displayed a very crystalline tenorite phase, but as the manganese content increases trough the samples, it becomes less crystalline and the CuO phase becomes less evident. There are no peaks assignable to MnO, MnO2, Mn2O3, Mn2O7, Mn3O4 or Mn5O8, in the mixed oxide diffractograms, possibly due to manganese incorporation into the CuO lattice and/or to the manganese phase not being crystalline enough to produce observable peaks. 3.1.2 Elemental composition and specific surface area Overall elemental composition results for the mixed oxides are shown in Table 1 . The most striking point is that the Cu/Mn ratios determined by ICP are much higher than the y values used in the syntheses. However, the Cu/Al ratios were fairly close to the nominal ones. This indicates that Mn was not completely incorporated in the LDH structure. This low manganese incorporation in the LDHs may be attributed to the differences in the ionic radii of the divalent metals with respect to the ionic radius of magnesium. The difficulty in forming LDHs with divalent cations increases as their ionic radius depart from that of magnesium (0.65 Å), and the Mn2+ ionic radius (0.80 Å) is significantly larger [11]. On the other hand, the Cu/Mn ratio in CuMn0.5pH8C, while still above the nominal one, was 3 to 5 times lower than the value found with other materials. The reason for this difference may be related to the pH of precipitation. In the co-precipitation of two or more hydroxides, it is usually necessary to precipitate in a pH larger than or equal to that where the most soluble hydroxide precipitates. The precipitation pH for copper and manganese hydroxides are 5.0 and 8.5, respectively [11]. While a LDH phase is not the same as a mixture of co-precipitated hydroxides, the use of the lower precipitation pH may have hampered the incorporation of manganese into the LDH structure. The CuMn0.5pH8C oxide has by far the largest Mn content. This may explain why it was the only material in whose precursor LDH no malachite phase was observed and had also the largest deviation in the a unit cell parameter as compared to the CuAl LDH. In the remaining materials the manganese concentration was not enough to avoid the formation of malachite and significantly affect the a parameter. Table 1 also shows values of the specific surface areas of the catalysts. Special attention must be given to CuMn0.5pH8C, which has a much larger specific surface area than the other mixed-oxides, including the commercial reference catalyst. Also included in this Table are specific surface area values for the binary CuAl (CupH6.5C) and MnAl (MnpH8C) mixed oxides. The specific surface area of MnpH8C is similar to that of CuMn0.5pH8C, while that of CupH6.5C is similar to those of the CuMnAl catalysts obtained from precursors precipitated at pH 6.5. Thus, the pH of precipitation of the precursor hydroxides seems to have an important effect on the specific surface areas of the corresponding mixed oxides. It may not be excluded that this effect is related to manganese incorporation in the catalysts, since both catalysts, whose precursors were precipitated at pH 8 had a larger manganese content. 3.1.3 Temperature-programmed reduction Results for the temperature-programmed reduction (H2-TPR) of the oxide catalysts are shown in Table 2 . The final temperature was defined at 538 K, which is the temperature of the catalytic test. The H2-TPR profiles are presented in Fig. S2. For all samples, reduction starts at ca. 433 K and with all of the CuMnAl catalysts, a maximum reduction rate occurs at 538 K. For CMSC and the MnAl material (MnpH8C) peak maxima appeared at somewhat lower temperature. With the CuMnAl catalysts prepared at pH 6.5 (low Mn contents), hydrogen uptakes per copper atom were similar to that of CMSC and somewhat larger than the one required to completely reduce Cu2+ to the metallic state. However, with CuMn0.5pH8C (high Mn content) the excess hydrogen consumption was much larger. The large hydrogen uptake obtained with the MnAl catalyst suggests that the excess hydrogen uptake in CuMn0.5pH8C is due to manganese reduction. In MnpH8C, there is only one reducible cation. It is generally accepted that manganese is not reduced to below the +2 oxidation state. Therefore, the nearly 1:1 hydrogen uptake per manganese atom in this catalyst suggests that manganese is in the +4 state in its oxide form. This analysis is more difficult to make in the case of the CuMnAl catalysts, since there are two reducible cations. However, assuming that copper is reduced from +2 to the metallic state, of the ca. 1.5 H2 uptake per Cu atom in CuMn0.5pH8R, 1.0 is involved in Cu reduction and 0.5 in Mn reduction. Since the real Cu/Mn mole ratio in this catalyst is ca. 2 (cf. Table 1),1.2 hydrogen molecule per Mn atom is involved in manganese reduction, which is in reasonable agreement with reduction of manganese from the +4 to the +2 state. 3.1.4 X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy Fig. 2 shows the high resolution XPS spectra in the Cu2p and Mn2p regions for the calcined materials. Mn2p spectra are essentially the same for all materials, exhibiting two main lines, namely Mn2p3/2 and Mn2p1/2 due to spin-orbit coupling. Copper spectra show the typical spin-orbit coupling along with satellite structures of the Cu2p line. The latter, positioned at ca. 9 eV apart from the main line, only appear in the Cu+2 oxidation state, confirming its presence in all samples [37,38]. Shake-up satellites arise when the outgoing photoelectron excites a valence electron to a bound unoccupied state. Because the photoelectron loses kinetic energy in the process, shake-up structures lie a few eV at higher binding energy than the main photoemission line. For Cu° and Cu+1, d-orbitals are completely filled, and in this manner, shake-up satellites are just related to Cu2+ with d9 electronic configuration. The Cu2p spectra from all mixed oxides are almost identical, and as can be seen in Table 3 , all Cu2p3/2 binding energies are in the range expected for Cu2+ close to but a little higher than the corresponding one in CuO. Mn2p3/2 binding energies are fairly close to that of Mn4+ in MnO2, which is in agreement with the estimate made from TPR. Al2p binding energies from mixed oxides are quite similar to that of Al+3 in Al2O3. Quantitation of surface composition from the XPS spectra was performed. This presents especial problems in the case of aluminum, due to overlap of the Cu3p with the Al2p line. Thus, the contribution of Cu3p to Al2p must be subtracted in order to quantify the surface Al concentration. This is described in more detail in the Supplementary Information (see also Fig. S3). Table 4 exhibits catalyst composition from XPS and they are compared with ICP analysis. The results show surface depletion in copper and surface enrichment in aluminum and manganese. Manganese surface concentration in CuMn0.5pH8C was significantly larger compared with CuMn0.5pH6.5C and CuMn2pH6.5C. The XPS results confirm the ICP ones with respect to the larger incorporation of manganese in CuMn0.5pH8. The surface depletion in copper may be related to partial encapsulation of the CuO-like phase by X-ray invisible amorphous Mn, Al, and/or Mn-Al phases during calcination. Similar observations have been reported in CuZn catalysts where the ZnO phase encapsulates CuO as observed by in situ transmission electron microscopy [39]. Notice that in relative terms the largest surface copper depletion occurs with CuMn0.5pH8C, which has the largest Mn/Cu ratio, where the possibility of segregation of a Mn-rich phase is more likely. 3.1.5 X-ray absorption spectroscopy of the mixed oxides In order to try and establish the differences in the environment of copper in the CuMnAl and the CuZnAl systems, CuMn05.pH8C and CMSC were characterized by X-ray absorption spectroscopy (XANES and EXAFS) near the Cu-K edge. Normalized N(μ(E)) and derivative D(μ(e)) XANES spectra for CuMn0.5pH8C, CMSC and the CuO and Cu2O standards are shown in Fig. 3 . E0 was obtained from the first intense maximum in the D(μ(e)) spectrum. The N(μ(E)), and D(μ(e)) spectra of CMSC are essentially identical to those of the CuO standard, exhibiting the same general features and E0. This is not the case with CuMn0.5pH8C, that lacks the structure on the rising edge [see N(μ(E))] associated with the 1 s→4p plus shakedown transition (excitation of 1 s electron to a 4p orbital with simultaneous ligand-to-metal charge transfer) [40]. This is more easily seen in the first derivative spectra, where both with CuO and CMSC a pronounced minimum is observed at 8986.5 eV. The lack of this feature is commonly observed in copper ionic compounds in solution where shakedown transitions do not to happen because of the lack of strong chemical bonds [41]. With CuMn0.5pH8C, this transition should be the low intensity minimum at ca. 8987.7 eV. Alp et al. [42], find that with KCuO2 (Cu3+) this transition (1 s→4p plus shakedown transition) is shifted to higher energy by ca. 2 eV with respect to CuO. The X-ray absorption edge, E0, in CuMn0.5pH8C is shifted to higher energy by 1.2 eV with respect to standard CuO, suggesting an oxidation state greater than two. However, increases in oxidation state are frequently accompanied by the shift to higher energy of the entire spectrum [42–44]. Note the unambiguous shift to lower energy of Cu2O when compared to CuO (see Fig. S4), in contrast with CuMn0.5pH8C. Structures at Cu K-edge XANES are sensitive to subtle variations due to both, local environment and valence state of the central atom and, as discussed, CuMn0.5pH8C 1 s→4p plus shakedown transition is apparently shifted by 1.2 eV to higher energy, this may be related to a more electro-deficient character of the copper, that may arise from the presence of either or both Mn4+ and Al+3 species in the copper vicinity. Cu K-edge EXAFS was performed attempting to establish coordination parameters for copper in the calcined and reduced versions of CuMn0.5pH8 and CMSC. The spectra measured at 323 K under He are presented in Fig. 4 . At the top are the Fourier transform magnitudes for CuO, CMSC and CuMn0.5pH8C and, at the bottom, are the imaginary parts of the respective Fourier transforms. As a starting point, the model to fit the data was based on the crystallographic information on tenorite CuO (ICSD16025), as this was the only phase identified in the mixed oxides, despite not being confirmed in CuMn0.5pH6.5C and CuMn0.5pH8C. Tenorite has a monoclinic crystal structure, with copper in a tetragonally distorted octahedral geometry because of the Jahn-Teller effect. Based on tenorite crystallographic information, copper´s first coordination shell has four oxygen atoms, two of them at a distance 1.95 Å and the other two at 1.96 Å, in a planar configuration. The amplitude of the first peak in the Fourier-transformed spectra is dominated by this Cu-O interaction. Copper´s second coordination has two oxygens at 2.78 Å (axially coordinated oxygen’s). Copper´s third coordination shell is ten-fold coordinated by copper. Four copper atoms are at 2.9 Å, followed by other four atoms at 3.08 Å. The last two copper atoms two are at 3.17 Å. The first peak, namely Cu-O backscattering, in the Fourier-transformed EXAFS Cu K-edge spectrum for CuMn0.5pH8C and CMSC are at the same position and have similar intensities to that of the CuO standard. The second major peak at an apparent distance ca. 2.5 Å is present in all samples, although with considerably diminished intensity in CuMn0.5pH8C. A third peak appears in the spectra of CMSC and CuO but is absent in CuMn0.5pH8C. There are two well-defined peaks at an apparent distance between 2–3 Å for CMSC and the CuO standard, which are not well defined in the spectrum of CuMn0.5pH8C. Therefore, CuO cannot explain the Cu K-edge EXAFS of CuMn0.5pH8C. This is the same trend observed in XRD and in the XANES Cu K-edge spectra. Peaks at apparent distances between 2–3 Å are dominated by Cu-O and Cu-metal backscattering. For CuMn0.5pH8C, the only apparent peak may have Cu-O, Cu-Cu, Cu-Mn, and Cu-Al contributions. Cu-Cu, Cu-Mn and Cu-Al backscattering pairs proved to be indistinguishable by EXAFS (models with only one type of back-scatterer fit the data equally well with copper, manganese or aluminum). Therefore, just the first coordination shell was modeled up to 2 Å. The best-fit output parameters are shown in Table 5 . Coordination numbers calculated from fitted data are in fair agreement with that of the first coordination shell in CuO. Bond-lengths are the expected ones for CMSC and CuO, but are slightly shorter for CuMn0.5pH8C. This agrees with XANES observations, since a more electron-deficient copper in a less covalent bond with oxygen relative to the Cu-O bond in CuO is expected to lead to a shorter bond-length. Characterization of the mixed oxides did not reveal the existence of a well-defined solid phase. The clearest thing is that oxidation states within the samples are around 2, 3 and 4, for copper, aluminum and manganese respectively. The predominant fourfold coordination of copper suggests that the coordination environment of copper in CuMn0.5pH8 is similar to that of CuO, with four oxide anions in a nearly square planar arrangement, but with considerable structural disorder in the second (Cu-O) and subsequent coordination spheres. There is probably the presence of Mn4+ and Al3+ in the vicinity of Cu2+ ions, which may account for the electron deficiency revealed by XANES. This is not surprising considering that in the LDH precursor phase, these elements are intimately mixed and may yield disordered solid solutions after calcination at relatively low temperatures [11]. Another plausible scenario is the existence of a disordered nanocrystalline CuO phase. Kondrat et al. [27] reported an XRD-amorphous CuO/ZnO catalyst in which a nanocrystalline copper oxide phase was observed. XANES and EXAFS data from the calcined catalyst are very similar to those of our CuMn0.5pH8 catalyst. In the same way, reduced catalyst showed a high copper surface area (53 m2 g−1) and a small copper crystallite size (7.4 nm), also very similar to CuMn0.5pH8. Belin et al. [45] reported Cu/Au catalysts with a well dispersed CuO phase with similar XANES and EXAFS results as ours. At the same time, quantification of the XPS data suggests that copper richer nanoparticles may be covered by a layer of a copper-poor phase. 3.2 Characterization of the reduced materials 3.2.1 Temperature-programmed reaction with in situ XRD analysis Fig. 5 shows the in situ XRD data obtained under 5% H2/He atmosphere. It is possible to see the disappearance of the poorly crystalline CuO-like phase and the appearance of a metallic Cu phase in all materials. Transition begins near the end of the temperature ramp and the metallic Cu stays well defined and crystalline during the temperature plateau. In order to obtain some insight on phase transitions, ramp diffractograms were analyzed in detail. The more intense peaks for Cu2O, CuO and Cu° lie at 2θ 36.5°, 35.6° and 43.32°, respectively. Presence of any of these 2θ peaks was taken as indication of the presence of the respective phases and relative intensities were interpreted as a measure of abundances of the phases. The CuO phase in CuMn2pH6.5C was stable until 498 K, then at 518 K disappeared completely and Cu2O was the only phase present. At the final stage of the ramp at 538 K both, Cu2O and Cu° are coexisting. CuMn0.5pH6.5C keeps the same XRD pattern as the initial oxide material until 478 K, where the nearly amorphous phase disappears and Cu2O is the only phase present. At 498 K Cu2O is the major phase but coexisting with Cu° that begins to appear. At 518 K Cu2O is still present together with Cu°, but abundances become approximately equal. Next, at 538 K, peaks corresponding to Cu2O cannot be differentiated from background and Cu° is the only visible phase, however peak intensities are lower compared with those of the isothermal stage. This observation agrees with QEXAFS (Quick Scanning EXAFS) [46] and Time-Resolved XANES [47] studies on CuO/ZnO/Al2O3 catalysts, where approximately all CuO is first transformed to Cu2O before passing to Cu° and, therafter, all Cu2O is reduced to zero-valent copper. CuMn0.5pH8C initially shows the nearly amorphous XRD patterns shown in Fig. 1. As early as 498 K, Cu° is evident accompanied with halos in the Cu2O and CuO reflections region. At 518 K all copper is present as Cu° without any sign of another phase. Peak intensities at 518 and 538 K in the ramp stage are the same as in the isothermal stage. These results show that, in all cases copper is reduced to the zerovalent state after reduction at 538 K, but reducibility follows the order CuMn0.5pH8C > CuMn0.5pH6.5C > CuMn2pH6.5C, that is the same order as increasing manganese concentration. Particle diameters for the crystallites (Dp) were estimated from the broadening of the XRD peaks, using Scherrer’s equation (see Experimental section for details) for the fully reduced samples. The results are shown in the last column of Table 6 . CuMn0.5pH8C has broader peaks, hence a smaller copper crystallite size. 3.2.2 X-ray absorption analysis of reduced materials Cu K-edge XANES of reduced samples (CuMn0.5pH8R and CMSCR) were collected. As shown in Fig. 6 , N(μ(E)) and D(μ(e)) spectra from CuMn0.5pH8R and CMSCR are in good agreement with those of copper foil. The E0 was determined on 8979 eV for all samples, the same as copper foil. At the reduction conditions used in the XAS experiments, there is no evidence for copper in any other than Cu° oxidation state. Cu K-edge EXAFS from CuMn0.5pH8R and the reference samples (CMSCR and copper foil) were performed to study the copper coordination state. Models to fit the EXAFS data were based on crystallographic information available (ICSD 53,247) for face-centered cubic copper. In its first coordination shell, copper has 12 neighbors at 2.55 Å in a cubic close-packed configuration. Interatomic bond lengths, coordination numbers and sigma square were fitted until 5.1 Å (see Table 7 ). As shown in Fig S5, Fourier transformed EXAFS spectra from CuMn0.5pH8R and CMSCR are identical to that of copper foil. First and second shell coordination numbers were smaller for the oxide-derived materials than for the copper foil, possibly because of incompletely coordinated copper atoms at the boundaries of the crystallites but were indistinguishable from each other within the confidence interval of the parameters. 3.2.3 Copper surface area and dispersion Copper metal surface areas (SCu) were determined by the N2O decomposition method (as described in detail under Supplementary Information). Briefly, N2O decomposes at 363 K on the copper surface to produce a surface oxide with a 2:1 copper to oxygen stoichiometry [48]. The surface oxygen is subsequently titrated by hydrogen using a H2-TPR procedure. The results are shown in Table 6. Despite having the lowest copper content, the metal surface area and dispersion of CuMn0.5pH8R are almost twice those of the other catalysts, including the commercial one. The dispersion is largest for CuMn0.5pH8R, which may be credited to the much larger specific surface area of the precursor oxide. Particle diameter for copper measured by N2O decomposition are in fair agreement with those calculated from X-ray broadening using Scherrer’s equation, supporting copper metal surface area results. 3.3 Catalytic performance Fig. 7 shows CO conversion results in the methanol synthesis reaction from syngas. CupH6.5R, MnpH8R and CMSCR were run as references. All catalysts showed good stability throughout the reaction. Equilibrium carbon monoxide conversion under our operation conditions (538 K, 50 bar, H2/CO = 2) is 46.5%, estimated based on real gas Berthelot model for fugacities and Lewis and Randall rule extrapolation for mixtures, using thermodynamic data and methodology as described by Thomas and Portalski [49]. Therefore, all measured conversions are far from the equilibrium value. Table 8 presents the results of the catalytic tests, in terms of methanol productivity (moles of methanol per kilogram catalyst per hour), selectivity to the different reaction products (moles of methanol converted to a given product per total moles of converted methanol) and turnover frequency (TOF) values with respect to copper, based on the N2O decomposition measurements. The productivity of CuMn0.5pH8R was significantly higher than that of the remaining catalysts. No previous reports were found in the literature on the performance of this kind of catalyst. The major product for all catalyst is methanol and selectivity for methanol production was also higher with CuMn0.5pH8R than with the remaining catalysts, including the commercial CuZnAl methanol synthesis catalyst. A synergetic effect between Mn and Cu is observed, since the productivities of all CuMnAl catalysts are larger than those of both the MnAl and the CuAl catalyst. The very low activity displayed by MnpH8R and the significant activity of CupH6.5R establishes that manganese acts as a promoter in the CuMnAl system. The TOF values relative to copper are seen to be very similar among the CuMnAl catalysts and CupH6.5R. Therefore, no effect of Mn on the intrinsic activity of copper may be deduced from the present results. These TOF values are, however, some 26% smaller than the one obtained with the CuZnAl catalyst, CMSCR. The high productivity obtained with CuMn0.5pH8R with respect both to the CuZnAl and the CuAl catalysts may then be credited largely to the higher copper surface area and dispersion of copper in the CuMnAl catalyst (cf. Table 7). This higher dispersion probably arises mainly from the large specific surface area of the CuMn0.5pH8C precursor mixed-oxide. Selectivity results indicate that both Zn and Mn function as basic additives to the catalysts. Both CuMn0.5pH8R, which has the largest manganese concentration among the CuMnAl catalysts, and CMSCR have the lowest selectivity to methanol dehydration to DME, a reaction that requires acidic sites. At the same time, all Mn-containing catalysts have lower selectivity to DME than CupH6R, and MnpH8R produces no DME. Comparison of CuMn0.5R and CMSCR shows that Mn seems to be more effective than Zn in decreasing catalyst acidity. CuMn0.5pH8R and CMSCR also share the lowest selectivity to CO2, with considerable advantage to the Mn-containing catalyst. This may be related to the smaller selectivity to DME displayed by CuMn0.5pH8R; methanol dehydration produces water that participates in CO2 production via WGSR, Reaction (1) below: Reaction (1) CO + H2O → CO2 + H2 Notice that MnpH8R also has a large selectivity to CO2, despite producing no DME. The water for WGSR must therefore come from another source, namely CO methanation, Reaction (2): Reaction (2) CO + 3H2 → CH4 + H2O Both methanol dehydration and CO methanation may serve as sources of water for WGSR in the case of CupH6R. In any case, the combination of copper with either zinc or manganese improves both the activity and selectivity in methanol synthesis. Productivities reported here may be compared to those reported both in the open and in the patent literatures for methanol synthesis in the liquid phase using CuZnAl catalysts (cf. Table S2). Typical values for industrial and laboratory reactors are around 17 mol methanol per kg catalyst per hour [50,51] and 5–16 mol methanol per kg catalyst per hour, respectively [52–54], under reaction conditions similar to ours. 4 Conclusions Carbonate-intercalated LDHs based on Cu, Mn and Al were successfully synthesized with varying Cu/Mn ratios and pH of precipitation, although the amounts of manganese incorporated into the catalysts were significantly smaller than the ones employed in the syntheses. The precipitating agents employed were sodium free, for which there are no previous reports in the literature for this system. The characterization of the mixed-oxides obtained by calcination of the LDH precursors showed that the material obtained from the LDH precursor precipitated at pH 8 (CuMn0.5pH8C) had significantly larger specific surface area and manganese content than the ones where the LDH precursor was precipitated at pH 6.5. It also had a larger specific surface area than a commercial catalyst belonging to the conventional CuZnAl group. This resulted in a considerably higher copper surface area and dispersion of the copper metal phase in the reduced form of this catalyst. X-ray absorption spectroscopic characterization showed that, in the calcined CuZnAl catalyst, the environment of copper is identical to that of a tenorite CuO phase. In CuMn0.5pH8C, copper appeared to be more electro-deficient than in CuO, probably because of the presence of manganese in a higher oxidation state and/or Al3+ in its vicinity or due to its existence as a defective nanocrystalline phase. In this catalyst, copper appeared to be fourfold coordinated by oxygen probably in a planar configuration, with considerable structure disorder from the second coordination sphere onwards. In the reduced catalysts, no difference in the electronic properties of copper between CuMn0.5pH8R, the reduced commercial CuZnAl catalyst and a copper foil standard were observed from the XANES data. In the syngas-to-methanol reaction in the liquid-phase, a synergetic effect between Cu and Mn was found. Catalyst CuMn0.5pH8, which has the largest manganese content among the CuMnAl materials, displayed the best methanol productivity and selectivity of all catalysts tested in this work. Also, the activity of CuMn0.5pH8 is comparable to, or better than, those reported in the literature for CuZnAl catalysts in the liquid-phase methanol synthesis reaction [50–54]. Its higher productivity with respect to CuZnAl and CuAl catalysts results mainly from the higher dispersion of the copper crystallites and consequently of the higher copper surface area in this CuMnAl catalyst. The results presented here do not imply that the catalysts described are “better” for industrial application in methanol synthesis than the commercial catalyst used for comparison, but they do imply that the CuMnAl system is worthy of further investigation aiming at practical use in this reaction. Catalysts obtained by calcination of the LDHs were characterized by EXAFS, XANES, XPS, ICP, XRD, TPR, N2O decomposition and BET, and were evaluated in the liquid-phase methanol synthesis reaction from synthesis gas. Characterization revealed that, in a commercial CuZnAl catalyst, the environment of copper is very similar to that prevailing in CuO. In the CuMnAl catalyst that presented the largest methanol synthesis activity, copper is more electron-deficient than in CuO and there is structural disorder beyond the first coordination sphere. TPR characterization suggests that manganese is in the 4+ oxidation state in the oxide precursor of this catalyst. The catalyst with the highest manganese content, y = 2.2, and prepared at higher pH, presented the highest methanol productivity and selectivity of all materials tested, including a commercial conventional CuZnAl catalyst, under our testing conditions. This was credited to the larger surface area of its oxide precursor, which resulted in smaller Cu crystallites and larger copper surface area than in the case of the remaining ones.
